Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Type of migration alogirthm.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MIG_TYPE
Type of migration alogirthm.
 
 Default = POST
 Allowed = SHOT       - Post stack migration.
 Allowed = COMAZ      - Common azimuth migration.
 Allowed = SHOT       - Shot profile migration. Not currently available.
 Allowed = PLANE_WAVE - Plane wave migration.
 Allowed = CLINDRICAL - Clindrical Wave migration.

Help.Tip: FORWARD or INVERSE migration.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MIG_DIR
FORWARD or INVERSE migration.
 
 Default = FORWARD
 Allowed = FORWARD FXMIG will forward migrate data.
 Allowed = INVERSE FXMIG will inverse migrate data.

Help.Tip: The dimensionality of the migration and data.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DIMENSION
The dimensionality of the migration and data.
 
 Default = 2D
 Allowed = 2D means 2D time or depth migration all y values assumed to be 0..
 Allowed = 3D means 3D time or depth migration.
 Allowed = M2D means 2D time or depth migration with multiple y values.

Help.Tip: Type of input and output order.
Help.Text:
fxmig - SORT_ORDER
Type of input and output order.
 
 Default = X_IS_FAST
 Allowed = X_IS_FAST data order is X - Y
 Allowed = Y_IS_FAST data order is Y - X

Help.Tip: Type of output parameter.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OUT_TYPE
Type of output parameter.
 
 Default = IMAGE
 Allowed = IMAGE
 Allowed = VELOCITY

Help.Tip: Print memory usage.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PRINT_MEMORY
Print memory usage.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO

Help.Tip: Apply a single pspi extrapolation to depth DEP_BULK.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OPT_BULK
Apply a single pspi extrapolation to depth DEP_BULK.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO

Help.Tip: Apply a single pspi extrapolation to depth DEP_BULK.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DEP_BULK
Apply a single pspi extrapolation to depth DEP_BULK.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Apply anti alias to imaging condition for shot migraton.
Help.Text:
fxmig - IMAGE_ANTI_ALIAS
Apply anti alias to imaging condition for shot migraton.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 Interpolate the x-y dimensions before applying the imaging condition
 for shot migration. This will not help for poststack migration. It is
 only relevant to prestack imaging where the image involves a product of
 source and receiver wavefields.

Help.Tip: Test option.
Help.Text:
fxmig - TEST_INDEX
Test option.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = integer
                   0 = standard operation
                   1 = use vertical sspi

Help.Tip: Header word indicating the X direction.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HDR_X
Header word indicating the X direction.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 1<=int<=64
 The number of image traces output may be less than X_TOT*Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: Header word indicating the Y direction.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HDR_Y
Header word indicating the Y direction.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 1<=int<=64
 The number of image traces output may be less than X_TOT*Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: Cylindrical direction.
Help.Text:
fxmig - CYLINDRICAL_DIR
Cylindrical direction.
 
 Default = X
 Allowed = X, Y

Help.Tip: Source gather flag.
Help.Text:
fxmig - SOURCE_GATHER
Source gather flag.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES,NO
 If SOURCE_GATHER=YES FXMIG assumes input is shot gathers.
 If SOURCE_GATHER=NO  FXMIG assumes input is receiver gathers.

Help.Tip: Receiver gather flag.
Help.Text:
fxmig - RECEIVER_GATHER
Receiver gather flag.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES,NO
 If RECEIVER_GATHER=NO  FXINFO will output info on shot gathers.
 If RECEIVER_GATHER=YES FXINFO will output info on receiver gathers.

Help.Tip: Depth scale coefficient.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DEP_SCALE
Depth scale coefficient.
 
 Default = 1000.
 Allowed = real>0

Help.Tip: Type of gather.
Help.Text:
fxmig - GAT_TYPE
Type of gather.
 
 Default = OFFSET
 Allowed = RAY
 Allowed = NONE
 Use OFFSET or RAY for Common Azimuth.
 Use OFFSET or RAY for Shot profile.
 Using RAY for Shot profile is still experimental.
 For common azimuth the output gather units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY
 For shot profile the output gather units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY

Help.Tip: Number of angle or offset groups for gathers.
Help.Text:
fxmig - ANG_TOT
Number of angle or offset groups for gathers.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>0
 The number of traces in offset or angle or ray parameter gathers for
 common azimuth and shot profile migration.
 For common azimuth the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY
 For shot profile the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY

Help.Tip: Minimum angle in the output image for angle gathers.
Help.Text:
fxmig - ANG_INIT
Minimum angle in the output image for angle gathers.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 The initial offset or angle or ray parameter for gather traces for
 common azimuth and shot profile migration.
 For common azimuth the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY
 For shot profile the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY

Help.Tip: Maximum angle in the output image for angle gathers.
Help.Text:
fxmig - ANG_LAST
Maximum angle in the output image for angle gathers.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 The last offset or angle or ray parameter for gather traces for
 common azimuth and shot profile migration.
 For common azimuth the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY
 For shot profile the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY

Help.Tip: Output image angle spacing for angle gathers.
Help.Text:
fxmig - ANG_INC
Output image angle spacing for angle gathers.
 
 Default = 25
 Allowed = real
 The offset or angle or ray parameter increment for gather traces for
 common azimuth and shot profile migration.
 For common azimuth the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY
 For shot profile the units are offset if GATHER_TYPE = OFFSET
 and micro seconds per length unit if GATHER_TYPE = RAY

Help.Tip: Number of offset groups.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_TOT
Number of offset groups.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>0

Help.Tip: Minimum offset in the output image.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_INIT
Minimum offset in the output image.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by velocity.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by
 OFF_TOT,OFF_INIT,OFF_LAST,OFF_INC the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Maximum offset in the output image.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_LAST
Maximum offset in the output image.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by velocity.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by
 OFF_TOT,OFF_INIT,OFF_LAST,OFF_INC the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Output image offset spacing.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_INC
Output image offset spacing.
 
 Default = 25
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by vleocity.
 If an input traces offset is outside the range defined by NOFF, OFFMIN, OFFINC
 the trace is discarded without migrating it.

Help.Tip: Number of image locations to migrate data to in the X direction.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_TOT
Number of image locations to migrate data to in the X direction.
 
 Default = 101
 Allowed = int>0
 The number of image traces output may be less than X_TOT*Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: First X image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_INIT
First X image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: Last X image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_LAST
Last X image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: X image location spacing to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_INC
X image location spacing to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.

Help.Tip: Number of image locations to migrate data to in the Y direction.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_TOT
Number of image locations to migrate data to in the Y direction.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>0
 The number of image traces output may be less than X_TOT*Y_TOT
 if no input traces are ever migrated to a portion of the image.

Help.Tip: First Y image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_INIT
First Y image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Last Y image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_LAST
Last Y image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Y image location spacing to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_INC
Y image location spacing to migrate data to.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.

Help.Tip: Number of image depth points to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DEP_TOT
Number of image depth points to migrate data to.
 
 Default = NDPT
 Allowed = int>0

Help.Tip: Minimum depth to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DEP_INIT
Minimum depth to migrate data to.
 
 Default = TSTRT * DEP_SCALE
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by the velocity.

Help.Tip: Maximum depth to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DEP_LAST
Maximum depth to migrate data to.
 
 Default = (NDPT-1)*DT+TSTRT
 Allowed = real>=DEP_INIT
 Units are defined by the velocity.

Help.Tip: Depth increment to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - DEP_INC
Depth increment to migrate data to.
 
 Default = DT * DEP_SCALE
 Allowed = real>0
 Units are defined by the velocity.

Help.Tip: Number of image time points to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - TIM_TOT
Number of image time points to migrate data to.
 
 Default = NDPT
 Allowed = int>0

Help.Tip: Minimum time to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - TIM_INIT
Minimum time to migrate data to.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real
 Units are defined by the velocity.

Help.Tip: Maximum time to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - TIM_LAST
Maximum time to migrate data to.
 
 Default = (NDPT-1)*DT+TSTRT
 Allowed = real>=TIM_INIT
 Units are defined by the velocity.

Help.Tip: Time increment to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - TIM_INC
Time increment to migrate data to.
 
 Default = DT
 Allowed = real>0
 Units are defined by the velocity.

Help.Tip: Number of X fft samples.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_FFT
Number of X fft samples.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = integer >= X_TOT
 Using -1 sets X_FFT to the next power of 2 > X_TOT
 FXMIG works best if X_FFT is a product of pwoers of 2,3 and 5

Help.Tip: Number of Y fft samples.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_FFT
Number of Y fft samples.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed -1, integer >= Y_TOT
 Using -1 sets Y_FFT to the next power of 2 > Y_TOT
 FXMIG works best if Y_FFT is a product of pwoers of 2,3 and 5

Help.Tip: Number of offset fft values.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_FFT
Number of offset fft values.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>0
 Used for common azimtuh migration.

Help.Tip: Number of TIME fft samples.
Help.Text:
fxmig - TIM_FFT
Number of TIME fft samples.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed -1, integer >= DEP_TOT
 Using -1 sets TIM_FFT to the next power of 2 > DEP_TOT
 FXMIG works best if TIM_FFT is a product of pwoers of 2,3 and 5

Help.Tip: X taper length.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_TAPER_LENGTH
X taper length.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed integer >= 0
 FXMIG will taper the horizontal fft a X_TAPER_LENGTH
 traces from either edge.

Help.Tip: X taper value at edge.
Help.Text:
fxmig - X_TAPER_VALUE
X taper value at edge.
 
 Default = .9
 Allowed real>=0
 FXMIG will taper the horizontal fft X_TAPER_LENGTH traces
 from either edge.

Help.Tip: Y taper length.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_TAPER_LENGTH
Y taper length.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed integer >= 0
 FXMIG will taper the horizontal fft a Y_TAPER_LENGTH traces
 from either edge.

Help.Tip: Y taper value at edge.
Help.Text:
fxmig - Y_TAPER_VALUE
Y taper value at edge.
 
 Default = .9
 Allowed real>=0
 FXMIG will taper the horizontal fft Y_TAPER_LENGTH traces
 from either edge.

Help.Tip: Offset taper length.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_TAPER_LENGTH
Offset taper length.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed integer >= 0
 FXMIG will taper the offset fft a OFF_TAPER_LENGTH
 traces from either edge.

Help.Tip: Offset taper value at edge.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OFF_TAPER_VALUE
Offset taper value at edge.
 
 Default = .9
 Allowed real>=0
 FXMIG will taper the offset fft OFF_TAPER_LENGTH traces
 from either edge.

Help.Tip: Use a CENTER or EDGES oriented aperture for the image summation.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OPT_AP_SUM
Use a CENTER or EDGES oriented aperture for the image summation.
 
 Default = EDGES
 Allowed = CENTER FXMIG will in sum into an aperture centered on the gather.
 Allowed = EDGES
 If OPT_AP_SUM = EDGES  FXMIG will in sum into an aperture centered on the
 edges of the gather.
 If OPT_AP_SUM = CENTER FXMIG will in sum into an aperture centered on the
 gather position.

Help.Tip: Yype of aperture definition, ANGLE or ARRAYS.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OPT_AP_TYPE
Yype of aperture definition, ANGLE or ARRAYS.
 
 Default = ANGLE
 Allowed = ANGLE
 Allowed = ARRAYS
 If OPT_AP_TYPE = ANGLE  FXMIG will use a constant aperture change with
 depth defined by the angles AP_X_ANG and AP_Y_ANG.
 If OPT_AP_TYPE = ARRAYS FXMIG will use a variable aperture change with
 depth defined by the arrays, AP_DEP, AP_X anf AP_Y.

Help.Tip: First X image location for shot migration.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_X_INIT
First X image location for shot migration.
 
 Default = X_INIT
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.
 AP_X_INIT, AP_X_LAST, AP_Y_INIT, AP_Y_LAST, define a maximum image area
 for shot profile migration.  The area for extrapolation of a shot
 will be limited to this area.  This allows the user to image a shot
 which falls outside the output image area.

Help.Tip: Last X image location for shot migration.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_X_LAST
Last X image location for shot migration.
 
 Default = X_LAST
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.
 AP_X_INIT, AP_X_LAST, AP_Y_INIT, AP_Y_LAST, define a maximum image area
 for shot profile migration.  The area for extrapolation of a shot
 will be limited to this area.  This allows the user to image a shot
 which falls outside the output image area.

Help.Tip: First Y image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_Y_INIT
First Y image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = Y_INIT
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.
 AP_X_INIT, AP_X_LAST, AP_Y_INIT, AP_Y_LAST, define a maximum image area
 for shot profile migration.  The area for extrapolation of a shot
 will be limited to this area.  This allows the user to image a shot
 which falls outside the output image area.

Help.Tip: Last Y image location to migrate data to.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_Y_LAST
Last Y image location to migrate data to.
 
 Default = Y_LAST
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_Y.
 AP_X_INIT, AP_X_LAST, AP_Y_INIT, AP_Y_LAST, define a maximum image area
 for shot profile migration.  The area for extrapolation of a shot
 will be limited to this area.  This allows the user to image a shot
 which falls outside the output image area.

Help.Tip: X aperture to maximum offset side of the gather.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_X_MAX
X aperture to maximum offset side of the gather.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.
 A negative value indicates a default setting and the actual value used
 will be abs ( AP_X_MAX )
 AP_X_MAX, AP_X_MIN, AP_Y_MAX and AP_Y_MIN define the extrapolation aperture
 for shot profile migration, measured from the shot position.
 They should all be posiitive.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute Y offset.

Help.Tip: X aperture to minimum offset side of the gather.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_X_MIN
X aperture to minimum offset side of the gather.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.
 A negative value indicates a default setting and the actual value used
 will be abs ( AP_X_MIN )
 AP_X_MAX, AP_X_MIN, AP_Y_MAX and AP_Y_MIN define the extrapolation aperture
 for shot profile migration, measured from the shot position.
 They should all be posiitive.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute Y offset.

Help.Tip: Angle, in degrees, for post migration, pre sum, mute.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_X_ANG
Angle, in degrees, for post migration, pre sum, mute.
 
 Default = 90.
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 90.
 FXMIG mutes the image from each gather above a line dipping at AP_X_ANG
 degrees from vertical measured from the extrema Y positions of the source
 and receivers within the shot gather before the shot image is stacked into
 the global image.  This reduces steep dip, low frequency noise.

Help.Tip: Y aperture to maximum offset side of the gather.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_Y_MAX
Y aperture to maximum offset side of the gather.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.
 A negative value indicates a default setting and the actual value used
 will be abs ( AP_Y_MAX )
 AP_X_MAX, AP_X_MIN, AP_Y_MAX and AP_Y_MIN define the extrapolation aperture
 for shot profile migration, measured from the shot position.
 They should all be posiitive.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute Y offset.

Help.Tip: Y aperture to minimum offset side of the gather.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_Y_MIN
Y aperture to minimum offset side of the gather.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = real
 Units are determined by HDR_X.
 A negative value indicates a default setting and the actual value used
 will be abs ( AP_Y_MIN )
 AP_X_MAX, AP_X_MIN, AP_Y_MAX and AP_Y_MIN define the extrapolation aperture
 for shot profile migration, measured from the shot position.
 They should all be posiitive.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_X_MAX , AP_X_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MAX ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the maximum absolute X offset.
 FXMIG will put the aperture defined by MIN ( AP_Y_MAX , AP_Y_MIN )
 on the side of the gather that has the minimum absolute Y offset.

Help.Tip: Angle, in degrees, for post migration, pre sum, mute.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_Y_ANG
Angle, in degrees, for post migration, pre sum, mute.
 
 Default = 90.
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 90.
 FXMIG mutes the image from each gather above a line dipping at AP_Y_ANG
 degrees from vertical measured from the extrema Y positions of the source
 and receivers within the shot gather before the shot image is stacked into
 the global image.  This reduces steep dip, low frequency noise.

Help.Tip: Depth array for depth - X, Y distance aperture.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_DEP
Depth array for depth - X, Y distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: X array for depth - X, Y distance aperture.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_X
X array for depth - X, Y distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Y array for depth - X, Y distance aperture.
Help.Text:
fxmig - AP_Y
Y array for depth - X, Y distance aperture.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Use io buffering that runs in a single job.
Help.Text:
fxmig - SINGLE_JOB_IO
Use io buffering that runs in a single job.
 
 Default = YES use single job style memory buffering.  Old FXSHOT buffering.
 Allowed = NO  use multi  job style memory buffering.  Old FXMIG buffering.

Help.Tip: Use io buffering that runs in multiple jobs.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MULTI_JOB_IO
Use io buffering that runs in multiple jobs.
 
 Default = NO  use single job style memory buffering.  Old FXSHOT buffering.
 Allowed = YES use multi  job style memory buffering.  Old FXMIG buffering.

Help.Tip: Image stage flag.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OPT_DISK_DEP
Image stage flag.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES     FXMIG will put data in disk buffers,
                   migrate and output all in one job.
 Allowed = NO      FXMIG will put data in memory buffers,
                   migrate and output all in one job.
 
 If OPT_DISK_MULTI = NO FXMIG stores this data in memory.  This is
 intended for 2D processing.
 Normally you should use OPT_DISK_DEP = YES for 3D processing.
 You can input and migrate multiple common offset sections in a single job.
 
 If OPT_DISK_DEP = YES FXMIG stores the data on disk.
 You can input and migrate multiple common offset sections in a single job.
 The image files are removed after processing.

Help.Tip: Image stage flag.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OPT_DISK_FREQ
Image stage flag.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES     FXMIG will put data in disk buffers,
                   migrate and output all in one job.
 Allowed = NO      FXMIG will put data in memory buffers,
                   migrate and output all in one job.
 If OPT_DISK_FREQ = NO FXMIG stores this data in memory.  This is
 intended for 2D processing.
 Normally you should use OPT_DISK_FREQ = YES for 3D processing.
 You can input and migrate multiple common offset sections in a single job.
 
 for the other values of OPT_DISK_FREQ FXMIG will store
 the frequency and depth images on disk.
 
 If OPT_DISK_FREQ = YES FXMIG stores the data on disk.
 You can input and migrate multiple common offset sections in a single job.
 The image files are removed after processing.

Help.Tip: Image stage flag.
Help.Text:
fxmig - OPT_DISK_MULTI
Image stage flag.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES     FXMIG will put data in disk buffers,
                   migrate and output all in one job.
 Allowed = NO      FXMIG will put data in memory buffers,
                   migrate and output all in one job.
 Allowed = INPUT   FXMIG will put data in disk buffers,
                   and stop after input without outputting any traces.
 Allowed = MIGRATE FXMIG will image data already in disk buffers,
                   and stop after imaging without outputting any traces.
 Allowed = OUTPUT  FXMIG will output imaged data for frequency files
                   FIRST_MIG_FILE to LAST_MIG_FILE
 Allowed = MIG_OUT FXMIG will migrate and output imaged data.
 
 If OPT_DISK_MULTI = NO FXMIG stores this data in memory.  This is
 intended for 2D processing.
 Normally you should use OPT_DISK_MULTI = YES for 3D processing.
 You can input and migrate multiple common offset sections in a single job.
 
 for the other values of OPT_DISK_MULTI FXMIG will store the frequency
 and depth images on disk.
 
 If OPT_DISK_MULTI = YES, INPUT,MIGRATE or OUTPUT
 FXMIG stores the data on disk.
 You can input and migrate multiple common offset sections in a single job.
 The image files are removed after processing.
 
 You are allowed to input and migrate  multiple common offset wavenumber
 sections in a single job.
 
 For the remaining values of OPT_DISK_MULTI
 You can image only one common offset section in a single job.
 The image files remain after processing and will need to be m=removed by
 hand after all processing is complete.
 
 Make sure you use the same set of input parameters for each of the three jobs
 in a OPT_DISK_MULTI =  INPUT, MIGRATE or OUTPUT, MIG_OUT job series.
 
 The frequency file names are constructed by assigning a prefix from the
 FREQ_PREFIX array in a round robin fashion and appending to that prefix
 the FILE_SUFFIX name and then appending an index number from 1 to
 NUMBER_MIG_FILE
 
 The depth image file names are constructed by assigning a prefix from the
 DEP_PREFIX array in a round robin fashion and appending to that prefix
 the FILE_SUFFIX name and then appending an index number from 1 to
 NUMBER_MIG_FILE
 
 If you are going to run concurrent FXMIG jobs for different offsets,
 make sure to use unique file names.
 
 FXMIG will create 4 different type of files
 An information file,  with the suffix head, which cntains the setup parmeters.
 The headers    file,  with the suffix h, which cntains the input trace headers
 The frequency  files, with the suffix w, which cntains the frequency images.
 The depth      files, with the suffix z, which cntains the depth     images.

Help.Tip: Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
Help.Text:
fxmig - CPUS_PER_GROUP
Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 fxmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by fxmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Number of parallel processing groups.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PAR_GROUPS
Number of parallel processing groups.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 fxmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by fxmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Total number of cpus in job.
Help.Text:
fxmig - NUM_CPUS
Total number of cpus in job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 fxmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by fxmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Put the entire depth image for each group on the root pe.
Help.Text:
fxmig - IMAGE_ON_ROOT
Put the entire depth image for each group on the root pe.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 If IMAGE_ON_ROOT = NO  the image is stored and handled by all pes.
 If IMAGE_ON_ROOT = YES the image is read and written only by the
 group root pe.
 
 The value of IMAGE_ON_ROOT should be tested for efficiency.

Help.Tip: Relative work load assigned to the root pe in each group.
Help.Text:
fxmig - LOAD_ON_ROOT
Relative work load assigned to the root pe in each group.
 
 Default = 1.
 Allowed = 0. <= LOAD_ON_ROOT <= 1.
 
 The LOAD_ON_ROOT is intended to allow the user to balance the work load
 across pes to improve efficieny.
 
 If IMAGE_ON_ROOT = YES the image is read and written only by the
 group root pe.  In that case hte group root pe is doing work the other
 group pes are not executing and it is possible that the work load will
 become unbalanced with a loss in efficiency.
 
 If LOAD_ON_ROOT = 1. the group root pe will be assigned as many frequency
 slices as any other pe in the group.  This means that if the group root pe is
 delayed by IO operations that other pes may not be used efficiently.
 
 If LOAD_ON_ROOT = 0. the group root pe will not be assigned any frequency
 slices.  This means the group will only have IO responsibilities and may not
 be used efficiently.
 
 It is recommended that LOAD_ON_ROOT be evaluated to find optimal performance.

 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO

 If initialize_trot is true and the files do not exist
 fxmig will create the files and initialize them.
 If initialize_trot is true and the files do not exist fxmig will abort.
 If initialize_trot is false and the files exist
 fxmig image the requested shots.
 If initialize_trot is false and the files do not exist
 fxmig will abort and tell the user to change initialize_trot to true.

Help.Tip: Name of model coefficient file.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PATH_MOD
Name of model coefficient file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 The X_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the x,z plane.
 The Y_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the y,z plane.
 For a horizontal geometry x_sin = y_sin = 0.
 For a 30 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .5
 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )
 If any PATH_MOD entry is other than NONE or CONST_MOD IS not equal to 0.
 AMOD assumes an anisotropic model.
 Then PATH_MOD(1) is the vZ values and the group velocity is
 1/v(a)**2 = cos(a)**2/vz**2 + sin(a)**2/vx**2 * (1 + 2*ETA*cos(a)**2 )
 If TYPE_TABLE_CALC = TIME, PATH_MOD(1) is assumed to be the stacking velocity.
 Otherwise, PATH_MOD(1) is assumed to be the vertical interval velocity.
 If PATH_MOD(2) is NONE the steep dip anisotropic coefficient is CONST_MOD

Power factor for input trace scaling used as T**PWR.

Help.Tip: Coefficient used in the EXP(BETA*T) factor.

 Default = 0.0

 If BETA == 0.0, trace value at time (T) is multiplied by T**PWR.
 If BETA /= 0.0, trace value at time (T) is multiplied by (T**PWR)*EXP(BETA*t)

 Allowed = real>0.
 If HEXT_OPT = RATIO
 use step size = step ratio * velocity / frequency (hertz)

Help.Tip: Preserve MIN_MAX or MID_LOC.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_RANGE_TYPE
Preserve MIN_MAX or MID_LOC.
 
 Default = MIN_MAX
 Allowed = MIN_LOC
 Allowed = MID_LOC
 if HEXT_RANGE_TYPE = MIN_MAX FXMIG will ensure that the minimum and maximum
 X,Y local range grid nodes will be preserved.
 if HEXT_RANGE_TYPE = MIN_MAX FXMIG will ensure that the minimum
 X,Y local range grid nodes will be preserved.
 if HEXT_RANGE_TYPE = MID_LOC FXMIG will ensure that the source
 X,Y local range grid node  will be preserved.
 if HEXT_TERP_TYPE_FREQ = 'FFT' or HEXT_TERP_TYPE_DEP = 'FFT'
 HEXT_RANGE_TYPE = MIN_LOC will be used.

Help.Tip: Apply the imaging condition on a CONSTANT or VARIABLE HEXT grid.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_TERP_OPT
Apply the imaging condition on a CONSTANT or VARIABLE HEXT grid.
 
 Default = FREQUENCY
 Allowed = DEPTH
 
 if HEXT_TERP_OPT = FREQUENCY FXMIG will apply the imaging condition on the
 constant local extrapolation grid.
 If using a variable horizontal extrapolation grid, this means the frequency
 slices are interpolated from the variable grid to the local grid before the
 imaging condition and the depth slice does not need to be interpolated
 after the imaging condition.
 
 if HEXT_TERP_OPT = DEPTH FXMIG will apply the imaging condition on the
 variable HEXT grid which may vary with frequency and depth.
 If using a variable horizontal extrapolation grid, this means the frequency
 slices are left on the variable grid for the imaging condition and the depth
 slices are interpolated from the variable grid to the local grid
 after the imaging condition.

Help.Tip: Type of frequency slice horizontal interpolation.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_TERP_TYPE_FREQ
Type of frequency slice horizontal interpolation.
 
 Default = LAGRANGE
 Allowed = LAGRANGE - Lagrange polynomial interpolation.
 Allowed = LINEAR   - less accurate than Lagrange
 Allowed = SPLINE   - very slow
 Allowed = SINC     - does not work yet.

Help.Tip: Frequency slice horizontal interpolation scale.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_TERP_PWR_FREQ
Frequency slice horizontal interpolation scale.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real
 scale interpolated frequency slice by
 ( nx_new / nx_old ) ** HEXT_TERP_PWR_FREQ
 This accounts for amplitude changes due to interpolation.

Help.Tip: Type of depth slice horizontal interpolation.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_TERP_TYPE_DEP
Type of depth slice horizontal interpolation.
 
 Default = LAGRANGE
 Allowed = LAGRANGE - Lagrange polynomial interpolation.
 Allowed = BILINEAR - bilinear interpolation.
 Allowed = LINEAR   - bilinear interpolation.
 Allowed = SPLINE   - very slow
 Allowed = SINC     - does not work yet.
 Allowed = FFT      - FFT interpolation.

Help.Tip: Depth slice horizontal interpolation scale.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_TERP_PWR_DEP
Depth slice horizontal interpolation scale.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real
 scale interpolated depth slice by ( nx_new / nx_old ) ** HEXT_TERP_PWR_DEP
 This accounts for amplitude changes due to interpolation.

Help.Tip: Number of hext states.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_NUM_GRIDS
Number of hext states.
 
 Default = 20
 Allowed = integer >= 1
 The analog extrapolation grids defined by HEXT_X_INC_LOW etc will be
 restricted to HEXT_NUM_GRIDS discrete bins.

Help.Tip: Variable horizontal extrapolation Interpolation X width.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HEXT_X_WID
Variable horizontal extrapolation Interpolation X width.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = -1, real>0.
 -1  means use 5 * X_INC
 This defines window widths for some interpolation methods
 such as Lagrange, SPLINE and SINC.
 Units are defined by HDR_X.

fxmig - HEXT_Y_WID

 Default = -1
 Allowed = -1, real>0.

 This defines window widths for some interpolation methods

Help.Tip: Ray parameter mute option.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MUTE_OPT
Ray parameter mute option.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = CONSTANT - use a constant mute depth of MUTE_CONST
 Allowed = ARRAYS   - use defined arrays of mute x, y, depth
 Only used for plane wave migrations.
 
 If there are N_MUTE_PX values in the MUTE_PX array
          and N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_PY array
 there should be
 N_MUTE_PX * N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_DEP array.
 The N_MUTE_PX - X values in the MUTE_PX array and the
 the N_MUTE_PY - Y values in the MUTE_PY array define a 2D grid on which the
 mute depths are defined in the MUTE_DEP array.
 These mute depths should be arranged in an X,Y order.
 That is :
 The first set of N_MUTE_PX values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the
 N_MUTE_PX different X values in the MUTE_PX array and the first
 Y value in the MUTE_PY array.
 The seoncd set of N_MUTE_PY values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the
 N_MUTE_PY different Y values in the MUTE_PY array and the second
 Y value in the MUTE_PY array.
 The acutal mute depth is computed via bilinear itnerpolation
 within the grid defined by MUTE_PX and MUTE_PY.

Help.Tip: Constant rayparameter mute depth.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MUTE_CONST
Constant rayparameter mute depth.
 
 Default = -999.
 Allowed = real
 If MUTE_OPT = CONSTANT the mute depth is set to MUTE_CONST
 for all ray parameters.
 If MUTE_OPT = CONSTANT and MUTE_CONST = -999.
 the mute depth is set to the maximum image depth for all ray parameters.

Help.Tip: Ray parameter mute taper length.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MUTE_TAPER_LENGTH
Ray parameter mute taper length.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real
 If MUTE_TAPER_LENGTH < 0.
 FXMIG use a taper length of 10 image depth samples.

Help.Tip: Mute X ray parameter value.
Help.Text:
fxmig - MUTE_PX
Mute X ray parameter value.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)
 
 If there are N_MUTE_PX values in the MUTE_PX array
          and N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_PY array
 there should be
 N_MUTE_PX * N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_DEP array.
 The N_MUTE_PX - X values in the MUTE_PX array and the
 the N_MUTE_PY - Y values in the MUTE_PY array define a 2D grid on which the
 mute depths are defined in the MUTE_DEP array.
 These mute depths should be arranged in an X,Y order.
 That is :
 The first set of N_MUTE_PX values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the
 N_MUTE_PX different X values in the MUTE_PX array and the first
 Y value in the MUTE_PY array.
 The seoncd set of N_MUTE_PY values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the
 N_MUTE_PY different Y values in the MUTE_PY array and the second
 Y value in the MUTE_PY array.
 The acutal mute depth is computed via bilinear itnerpolation
 within the grid defined by MUTE_PX and MUTE_PY.

Mute Y ray parameter value.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)
 
 If there are N_MUTE_PX values in the MUTE_PX array
          and N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_PY array
 there should be
 N_MUTE_PX * N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_DEP array.
 The N_MUTE_PX - X values in the MUTE_PX array and the
 the N_MUTE_PY - Y values in the MUTE_PY array define a 2D grid on which the
 mute depths are defined in the MUTE_DEP array.
 These mute depths should be arranged in an X,Y order.
 That is :
 The first set of N_MUTE_PX values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the
 N_MUTE_PX different X values in the MUTE_PX array and the first
 Y value in the MUTE_PY array.
 The seoncd set of N_MUTE_PY values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the

 The acutal mute depth is computed via bilinear itnerpolation

Help.Tip: Depth values for ray parameter mute.

Depth values for ray parameter mute.
 
 Default = 0

 If there are N_MUTE_PX values in the MUTE_PX array
          and N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_PY array
 there should be
 N_MUTE_PX * N_MUTE_PY values in the MUTE_DEP array.
 The N_MUTE_PX - X values in the MUTE_PX array and the
 the N_MUTE_PY - Y values in the MUTE_PY array define a 2D grid on which the
 mute depths are defined in the MUTE_DEP array.
 These mute depths should be arranged in an X,Y order.
 That is :

 The seoncd set of N_MUTE_PY values from the MUTE_DEP array refer to the

Help.Tip: Type of extrapolation step.
Help.Text:
fxmig - EXT_TYPE
Type of extrapolation step.
 
 Default = PSPI
 Allowed = PSPI,      Phase shift plus interpolation. SPLIT STEP and SCREEN
 Allowed = MCCLELLAN, McClellan transform.  For zero offset only.
 Allowed = IMPLICIT,  Implicit finite difference from SALVO
 Allowed = FFD,       Optimized Implicit finite difference
 Allowed = RYTOV,     Rytov algorithm.
 Allowed = NONE,      none
 Stoffa, P. L., Fokkema, J. T., de Luna Freire, R. M. and Kessinger, W. P.,
 1990, Split-step Fourier migration: Geophysics, 55, no. 04, 410-421.

Help.Text:
fxmig - MIG_DIAG_LOAD
Deconvolution diagonal load.
 
 Default = 0.05
 Allowed = real >= 0. Deconvolution diagonal load.

Help.Text:
fxmig - MIG_CON
Type of imaging condition, CORRELATION or DECONVOLUTION.
 
 Default = CORRELATION
 Allowed =   CORRELATION FXMIG will use a   correlation imaging condition.
 Allowed = DECONVOLUTION FXMIG will use a deconvolution imaging condition.

Help.Tip: Use phase only for shot profile correlation imaging condition.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PHASE_ONLY
Use phase only for shot profile correlation imaging condition.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES Normal correlationimaging condition.

Help.Tip: Skip the extrapolation - for testing.
Help.Text:
fxmig - SKIP_EXTRAPOLATION
Skip the extrapolation - for testing.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES Used for testing.

Help.Tip: Constraints imposed at sides of computational grid.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXFD_BC
Constraints imposed at sides of computational grid.
 
 Default = NEUMANN
 Allowed = NEUMANN   Pressure field has zero slope condition
 Allowed = DIRICHLET Pressure field has zero value condition
 Allowed = TAPER     Apply a rolloff taper at edges
 Allowed = ABCTAPER  Apply a ABC plus rolloff taper at edges
 Allowed = ABC1      Apply a local Absorbing BC (Clayton Enquist  B3)
 Allowed = ABC2      Apply a local Absorbing BC (Xu)
 Allowed = TEST      A hook for developer testing
 Not all migration options will support this feature. At present only
 the FFD and IMPLICIT migrations allow a choice of BC . Other options
 such as PSPI will impose cyclic BCs because the algorithm works in the
 wavenumber domain.

fxmig - FXFD_WRAP
.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = integer >=0   The length of the wrap-around absorber
 Used for FXFD.

Help.Text:
fxmig - FXMC_LENGTH
FXMC operator half length.
 
 Default = 19
 Allowed integer >= 5

Help.Tip: FXMC operator type.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXMC_TYPE
FXMC operator type.
 
 Default = 4
 Allowed = 0 -- 2D
 Allowed = 1 -- 9-point filter
 Allowed = 2 -- 17-point filter
 Allowed = 3 -- 9-point rotated filter
 Allowed = 4 -- Alternating  9-point with 9-point rotated filters
 Allowed = 5 -- Alternating 17-point with 9-point rotated filters

Help.Tip: FXIMP boundary condition width.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXIMP_LENGTH
FXIMP boundary condition width.
 
 Default = 16
 Allowed integer >= 1

Help.Tip: FXIMP boundary condition value.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXIMP_VALUE
FXIMP boundary condition value.
 
 Default = .001
 Allowed real >= 0.

Help.Tip: FXIMP Li filter apllication rate.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXIMP_LI_INC
FXIMP Li filter apllication rate.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed integer >= 0
 Rate at which the Li filter correction is applied during the implicit
 extrapolation.
 The Li filter corrects for numerical anisoptropy during the extrapolation
 and involves a forward and inverse 2D fft over x,y.
 If FXIMP_LI_INC=1 the cost of the Li filter may be close to that of the
 implicit exptrapolation, double ing the cost of the migration.
 The Li filter corrects for numerical anisoptropy during the extrapolation
 FXIMP_LI_INC=1 means the Li correction is applied every depth step.
 FXIMP_LI_INC=2 means the Li correction is applied every other depth step.
 FXIMP_LI_INC=0 means the Li correction is never applied.

Help.Tip: Min veloicty for Li filter.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXIMP_LI_VEL
Min veloicty for Li filter.
 
 Default = -11
 Allowed real
 Eventualy if FXIMP_LI_VEL < 0. FXIMP will use the minimum velocity
 at each depth for the Li filter.
 Currently if FXIMP_LI_VEL < 0. FXIMP will use the following to determine
 the max li filter velocity
    xxif_set_as_bound : if ( fximp_obj%fximp_li_vel .gt. 0. ) then
      fximp_obj%as_bound = 1. / fximp_obj%fximp_li_vel
    else if ( string_upper_compare ( survey_units(1:4), 'FEET' )) then
      fximp_obj%as_bound = 0.000075   !1/13333
    else xxif_set_as_bound
      fximp_obj%as_bound  = 0.00025    !1/4000
    end if xxif_set_as_bound

Help.Tip: Type of velocity funciton used to compute range of reference vel.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXPS_REF_TYPE
Type of velocity funciton used to compute range of reference vel.
 
 Default = MINIMUM
 Allowed = MINIMUM  - use MINIMUM velocity within range.
 Allowed = AVERAGE  - use AVERAGE velocity within range.
 Allowed = MAXIMUM  - use MAXIMUM velocity within range.
 Allowed = X_Y_LOC  - use the velocity at FXPS_REF_X, FXPS_REF_Y
 Allowed = CONSTANT - use an analytic reference velocity
 FXPS_REF_TYPE controls how the reference functions is set for each depth.
 if a single reference function is used at a given depth.
 Using FXPS_REF_TYPE = MINIMUM - use a minimum velocity.
 Using FXPS_REF_TYPE = AVERAGE - use an average slowness.
 Using FXPS_REF_TYPE = MAXIMUM - use a maximum velocity.
 Using FXPS_REF_TYPE = X_Y_LOC - use the velocity at FXPS_REF_X, FXPS_REF_Y
 Using FXPS_REF_TYPE = CONSTANT - use the velocity defined
 by FXPS_REF_CONSTANT, FXPS_REF_GRADIENT and FXPS_REF_DEPTH

Help.Tip: Type of velocity average used to compute range of reference vel.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXPS_REF_RANGE
Type of velocity average used to compute range of reference vel.
 
 Default = LOCAL
 Allowed = LOCAL  - use local  velocity range for refrence function.
 Allowed = GLOBAL - use global velocity range for refrence function.
 REF_RANGE controls how the range of reference functions is set for each depth.
 Using REF_RANGE = GLOBAL - use a global velocity range for refrence function.
 Hence every depth will have the same range of reference functions.
 Using REF_RANGE = LOCAL - use a local velocity range for refrence function.
 Hence every depth will have a different range of reference functions.

Help.Tip: Make offset ffts symetric.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXPS_SYM_OFF
Make offset ffts symetric.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO
 Allowed = YES
 This is used for common azimuth migration.
 If FXPS_SYN_OFF = YES FXMIG will assume that the offset fft's are symetric
 and will set the frequency slice negative offset values equal to the
 positive values before each fft.
 Make sure your offset fft value is large enough to include both
 positive and negative values.

Help.Tip: Carry along negative offsets in memory.
Help.Text:
fxmig - FXPS_NEG_OFF
Carry along negative offsets in memory.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO
 Allowed = YES
 This is used for common azimuth migration.
 If FXPS_NEF_OFF = NO FXMIG will assume that the offset fft's ar symetric
 and will not carry the negative offsets in memory.
 Set your min offset to zero.
 Make sure your offset fft value is large enough to include both
 positive and negative values.

fxmig - FXPS_VAL_TYPE
Type of velocity average used to compute range of reference vel.
 
 Default = LOCAL
 Allowed = LOCAL  - use local  evanescent zone.
 Allowed = GLOBAL - use global evanescent zone.
 VAL_TYPE controls the range of wabenumbers which are actualy migrated.
 Using VAL_TYPE=GLOBAL sets the evanescent zone to that of the most

 Using VAL_TYPE=LOCAL sets the evanescent zone to that of the local

 TERP_TYPE Controls how wavefield for different v(z) reference functions

 Default = 1.0

 When the PLOT_DATA button is pressed the data will be plotted.

fxmig - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

fxmig - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Text:
fxmig - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
fxmig - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
fxmig - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
fxmig - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
fxmig - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : FXMIG
 Category   : Migrations
 Written    : 2001-02-02  by: Douglas Hanson
 Revised    : 2006-04-25  by: Douglas Hanson Remove unreferenced variables.
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Shot profile, common azimuth and post stack FX migration.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : Yes
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 Shot profile, common azimuth and post stack FX migration.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
                        INPUT PARAMETERS
 
 Name  Default  Valid    Description
 ----  -------  -----    -----------
 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
 This process is re-enterable.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 notes
 
1. FXMIG images data uses a number of different algorithms including:
   Shot profile, indcluding plane wave and cylindrical wave migrations.
   Common azimuth Post stack.
 
2. FXMIG can both migrate and model data for Post stack and common azimuth
   algorithms. FXMIG can not model shot profile data.
 
3. For all methods FXMIG accepts standard CPS trace flow inputs.
 
4. For Shot profile migration FXMIG allows a special internal io method
   for data input and output.
 
5. FXMIG allows the use of a number of different wavefield extrapolators,
   controled by the parameter EXT_TYYP.
 
6. FXMIG has the flexibility to input, process and output the data and images
   in several different ways depending upon the parameters:
   SINGLE_JOB_IO and MULTI_JOB_IO.
 
   If SINGLE_JOB_IO = YES, MULTI_JOB_IO = NO,
   and FXMIG inputs and outputs data in a single job.
   This is the recommend method for shot profile and small common azimuth
   and post stack migrations.
 
   If SINGLE_JOB_IO = NO, MULTI_JOB_IO = YES,
   and FXMIG inputs and outputs data in a series of more than one job.
   This is designed for data volumes which are too large to be held in memory.
   Then the input data is input in one job and placed into a series of
   disk files in frequency slice order.
   Then a series of jobs are run to image the various frequecy slices and add
   the contribution for each frequency to the image volume.
   This approach only requires enough memory for a single frequency slice
   and is recommended for large post stack or common azimuth migrations.
 
7. File names are constructed using the following parameters
 
   FILE_PREFIX
 
9. When using shot profile migration and internal io,
   FXMIG will break the job processors into PAR_GROUPS groups. Each
   group will image a subset of the input shots and construct
   an image independantly from the other groups.  At the end
   of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
   by FXMIG and the result output on all pes.
   It is strongly reccommended that you the number of
   processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of PAR_GROUPS ,
   so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
   also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
   The maximum number of processors in any group is :
   m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
   The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
   n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
   The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
   n_pe_grp_1 = PAR_GROUPS - n_pe_grp_2
   cpus into PAR_GROUPS groups of cpus.  Each group of cpus will act
   together to image a single shot gather with a subset of frequency slices
   assigned to each cpu within a group.
 
 
 
9. internal io.
 
 If INTERNAL_IO=YES FXMIG will read data traces from trin file
 list within the FXINFO file.
 and migrate different shots on different processor groups.
 
 It will then write out the image traces to the trot file described above
 Each time a group of processors completes a set
 of NUM_STACK shots it will add the image for that set of shots to the
 trot file/
 FXMIG will keep a list of the shots stacked into the trot file in
 the INFO_TROT file.
 
 FXMIG will not image any input trace from outside in this mode.
 
 The shot gathers read and processed by FXMIG are indicated by parameters,
 SHOT_MAX, SKIP_INIT, NUM_DO, and NUM_SKIP.
 
 This allows the user to migrate different parts of the input data file
 efficiently.
 
 When FXMIG recieves the first input trace it will begin to read traces from
 from FXINFO defined trin file according to the pattern defined by
 SHOT_MAX, SKIP_INIT, NUM_DO, and NUM_SKIP and distribute them
 to different processing groups for imaging in a round robin fashion.
 
 Note, If INTERNAL_IO=YES FXMIG will not return above for
 any more input traces, nor will it output any traces below.
 
 The info file INFO_TRIN must be constructed by FXINFO
 before running FXMIG
 
 The info file INFO_TRIN has information on each shot gather in the data
 set including the first and last trace locations.
 
 Parameter MIN_IN_GATHER is the minimum number of traces in a shot which
 will be migrated by FXMIG if INTERNAL_IO=YES.
 Shot gathers with less than MIN_IN_GATHER traces will not be migrated.
 The DO - SKIP selection of shots is unaffected by MIN_IN_GATHER.
